ŁPāda$ a is reminiscent of, among other famous passages, \BHG\ 11.19: Łanādimadhyāntam anantavīryam
anantabāhuṃ śaśisūryanetram |
paśyāmi tvāṃ dīptahutāśavaktraṃ
svatejasā viśvam idaṃ tapantam ||$. See also \BHG\ 10.20cd: Łaham ādiś ca madhyaṃ ca bhūtānām anta eva ca$ ||. A faint reference to the \BHG\ seems proper at the beginning of a work that claims to deliver a teaching based on, but also to surpass, the \MBH\ (see following verses of the \VSS). Compare also, e.g., \KURMP\ 1.11.237: Łrūpaṃ tavāśeṣakalāvihīnam
agocaraṃ nirmalam ekarūpam |
anādimadhyāntam anantam ādyaṃ
namāmi satyaṃ tamasaḥ parastāt$ ||. To say that a god has no beginning and no end in a temporal or spacial sense is natural (Łanādi...antam$), but to have no `middle part' (Łmadhya$) in these senses is slightly less so. Thus the rather commonly occuring phrase Łanādimadhyāntam$ is probably a fixed expression usually referring to a deity that is endless, eternal and immaterial. As to which deity or what form of a deity this stanza refers to, it may be Śiva, his name missing in pāda c, but the phrasing of the verse is vague enough to keep the question somewhat open: the impersonal Brahman might be another option, even more so if we look at verses 1.9–10, whose topic is Łbrahmavidyā$. In Łpāda$ b Łjagat-susāraṃ$ is most probably not to be interpreted as Łjagatsu sāraṃ$ (`the essence in the worlds'). Another way to translate Łavyaktajagatsusāraṃ$ would be: `who is the fine essence of the unmanifest world.' Strictly speaking, Łpāda$ c is unmetrical, but it is better to simply acknowledge here the phenomenon of `muta cum liquida', namely that syllables followed by consonant clusters such as Łra, bra, hra, kra, śra, śya, śva, sva, dva$ can be treated as short (Łlaghu$). (See Introduction \CHECK) Thus Łharīndrabrahmā$ can be treated as a regular beginning of an Łupajāti$ (\shortsyllable\ - \shortsyllable\ - -), the syllable Łbra$ not turning the previous syllable long (Łguru$). The reading Łāsamagraṃ$ in Łpāda$ c is suspect, although the initial Łā-$ might convey some sort of completeness, meaning `all round' (see e.g. KaleHigherGrammar226). The fact that we could percieve the ending of Łpāda$s a and b (Łpāraṃ$–Łsāram$), as well as Łpāda$s c and d, as (in the latter case, oddly) rhyming pairs (Łgraṃ$-Łgraham$) suggests that accepting the reading Łāsamagram$ could be the right decision (as suggested by Alessandro Battistini). I translate this verse accordingly. \msM\ gives an exciting, albeit unmetrical, alternative (Łyat samagraṃ$), but this seems more like a guess to me than the correct reading. For some time I was considering emending Łāsamagraṃ$. The most tempting of all the possible options (Łarcyam/arhyam/arghyam/īḍyam/āḍhyam agraṃ, āsamastaṃ$) seemed to be Łāptam agraṃ$, meaning `appointed/received/respected [by Hari, Indra, Brahmā etc.] as the foremost one'. The fact that the Łakṣara$s Łāsam$ and Łāptam$ look similar in most of the scripts used in our manuscripts could support this conjecture. Łāptam$ could also possibly refer to the text itself, although then the syntax becomes slightly confusing: `I shall recite the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ that was first received by Hari...' etc. Another candidate was Łāḍhyam agram$: `Having bowed to [Him] who contains/is rich with Hari, Indra, Brahmā etc.' I have not emended the text because it is difficult to know if there is any need for change and if there is, which reading to chose. There was no consensus when this verse was discussed in our extended Śivadharma reading group. Pāda d seems hypermetrical, but it can be interpreted as a Łvaṃśastha$ line, a change from Łtriṣṭubh$ to Łjagatī$ (as suggested by Dominic Goodall).

The dialogue of Janamejaya and Vaiśampāyana makes up the outermost layer of the \VSS\ (except for the introductory stanzas 1.1–3; see Introduction \CHECK), mostly containing general Łdharmaśāstric$ material. That the \MBH\ should contain a hundred thousand verses is hinted at e.g. in line 19 of the Khoh Charter 2 of Śarvanātha, year 214 (Siddham IN00088: Łuktañ ca mahābhārate śatasāhasryaṃ$ (understand Łryāṃ$) Łsaṃhitāyāṃ$... The hundred Łparvan$s of the ŁMahābhārata$ are listed in \MBH\ 1.2.33–70.

My emendation from the unmetrical Łpunaḥ$ to the unusual, or rather, Middle Indic (EdgertonHybridvol. 2, p. 347), Łpuna$ is based on the assumption that in the original the metre must have overridden morphology, similarily to what may have happened in 8.44d (Mālinī metre): Łna bhavati punajanma kalpakoṭyāyute 'pi$, and in 12.151c (Sragdharā metre): Łgarbhāvāsaṃ na ca tvan na ca punamaraṇaṃ kleśam āyāsapūrṇam$. For an unsatisfaction or dissatisfaction (Łatṛpti$) with previous teachings in a somewhat similar manner to what Janamejaya experiences here, see e.g. ŁNiśvāsa$ mūla 1.9: Łvedāntaṃ viditaṃ deva sāṃkhyaṃ vai pañcaviṃśakam | na ca tṛptiṃ gamiṣyāmo hy ṛte śaivād anugrahāt ||$; and the \SDhS\... \CHECK.

Vaiśampāyana, a Ṛṣi, disciple of Vyāsa, great-grandson to Arjuna, recited the Mahābhārata at the snake sacrifice of Janamejaya. This setting is an echo of the starting point of the Mahābhārata, see \MBH\ 1.1.8ff. In fact the next few verses in the \VSS\ make it clear that the \VSS\ picks up where the Mahābhārata left off: Janamejaya has heard the whole Mahābhārata from Vaiśampāyana, but he is eager to hear more. Note how we are forced to emend Łpāda$ c to contain a stem form proper noun (Łjanamejaya$) to maintain the metre, and note how the manuscripts struggle with this Łpāda$. Stem form nouns, Łprātipadika$s, abound in the \VSS: see Introduction p. \CHECK.
Note Łdharma$ as a neuter noun in Łpāda$ c and in the next verse.

The majority of the MSS consulted include a Łvā$ in Łpāda$ b, and although \msCb's reading seems a bit smoother, that manuscript rarely gives superior readings. Therefore I have chosen Łdharmaṃ vā yad$, in which Łvā$ functions probably in a weak sense. That the secret Dharma Janamejaya is seeking is the one taught by Vyāsa Dvaipāyana, and thus no real options are involved here, becomes clear in 1.6cd. The reading of \msM\ in Łpāda$ b (Łdharmavākyaṃ$) is tempting but could be a later correction.
In general, \msM's readings here are unique but probably secondary: Łhi me tṛptiṃ$ in Łpāda$ c seems more attractive than \msM's Łprasādena$ because it echoes Łatṛptaḥ$ in 1.3a

Note the odd syntax here: Łviṣṇunā... dvijarūpadharo bhūtvā papraccha$. The agent of the active verb is in the instrumental case (anacoluthic structure). On Anarthayajña, the interlocutor of VSS 1.9–10.2 and 19.1–21.22, and an important figure discussed in 22.3ff, as well as a concept (`nonmaterial sacrifice'), see KissVolume2021 and Introduction \CHECK.

The translation of this verse, and the reconstruction and interpretation of Łpāda$ d, which is echoed in 1.10d, is slightly tentative. I doubt if Łkimu$ could have the standard (Vedic) meaning `how much more/less' here. Rather Łu$ is probably just an expletive. In general it seems that this verse references the syllable Łoṃ$.

The word Łśivā$ in Łpāda$ b is slightly suspect, and could be the result of metathesis, from Łviṣā$ (`by poison'). Nevertheless, jackals seems appropriate in this context, for they are commonly associated with human corpses, death and the cremation ground (see e.g. Ohnuma2019). Furthermore, Łpāda$ b lists phenomena that cause the body to disintegrate, and not causes of death; thus the reading Łśiva$ is probably correct.

The word Łkāla$ has, as usual, a double meaning here: Łkālapāśa$ is both Yama's noose, and also the limitations and bondage caused by time, as becomes clear at the discussion on the different time units in verses 1.18–31.
Note Łte$ used for Łtvayā$ in Łpāda$ a. Alternatively, taking Łte$ as genitive, the line could be translatied as: `I am being asked about a great problem of yours that originates in doubts\dots'

The MSS give Łkarmahetu$ in Łpāda$ a overwhelmingly, which could work as a neuter Łbahuvrīhi$ compound picking up both Łutpattir$ and Łnidhanaṃ$ but Łkarmahetuḥ$ is grammatically more correct, picking up the feminine Łutpatti$. I suspect that there may have been a confusion, scribes taking Łkarmahetuśarīrasya$ as one single compound; but this would make it difficult to interpret the verse.
The variant Łjijñāsyasi$ seems to be the lectio difficilior as opposed to Łvijñāsyasi$, but the latter could also work fine here.
Note how \msM\ (agreeing with \Ed) gives a reading (Łvaktum arhasi$) that is clearly out of context. This confirms that while \msM\ comes up with interesting readings, they are mostly to be ignored.

1.18d and 1.19a are problematic in the light of 1.19b, which redefines Łkalā$ in harmony with the traditional interpretaion, see e.g. ŁArthaśāstra$ 2.20.33: Łtrimśatkāṣṭhāḥ kalāḥ$. Arthasastra1969 On divisions of time, see also, e.g., \Manu\ 1.64ff. I have calculated 1.6 second for one Łkalā$ backwards, starting from one day (see 1.20ab).
Note how a verb (e.g. Łiti vadanti, iti prāhur$) is missing in the first half-verse.
Note the stem form noun Łyuga$ metri causa, and also \msM's unique but confused readings.

The `figure' mentioned in this verse is the sum of the duration of the four Łyuga$s, which makes up one Łmahāyuga$: Kaliyuga = 360,000 years, Dvāparayuga = 720,000 years, Tretāyuga = 1,080,000 years, Dvāparayuga = 1,440,000 years; altogether 3,600,000 years. 72 Łmahāyuga$s make up a Łmanvantara$ (= 259,200,000 years). One Łkalpa$ is 14 Łmanvantara$s (= 3,628,800,000 years). Ten thousand Łkalpa$s are one day of Brahmā, and his night is of the same length, which makes one full day of Brahmā 72,576,000,000,000 years. See next verses.
See 21.34ff.
\msM\ has a separator sign (|o|) at the end of Łpāda$ b, as if a section ended here.

The plural form Łpralīyante$ in Łpāda$ a is metri causa for Łpralīyate$, perhaps also influencing Łutpadyante$ (for Łutpadyate$) in Łpāda$ d, which in turn is used here to avoid an iambic pattern (- - \shortsyllable\ - \shortsyllable\ - \shortsyllable\ -).
On the definition of the numbers Łpara$ and Łparārdha$, see verses 1.32–36.
Note the peculiar compound Łbhṛgu-r-ādi-maharṣayaḥ$.

Łbhramato$ (gen.) in Łpāda$ b seems to stand for the neuter participle Łbhramat$. Alternatively, Łbhramato$ might mean `erroneously' (Łbrama-tas$, abl.), but this makes the verse difficult to interpret.

The use of the singular next to numerals is one of the hallmarks of the \VSS\ (see p. \verify). As an introduction to this phenomenon, Łpāda$ a has Łbrahmāṇḍaṃ$ in the singular where we would expect a plural form. The word Łprāpitaṃ$ is a conjecture for Łcāpitaṃ$, which I find unintelligible. Another possibility could be Łjñāpitaṃ$.

My emendation of Łcāṅguli-mūrdheṣu$ to Łcāṅguli{-}m{-}ūrdhveṣu$ (with a hiatus filler) is based on Łūrdhvatas$ in 1.61d, which is part of the reply to the question posed in this line. In turn, Łaṅguli$ here triggered an conjecture in 1.61c.

One would expect Łbrahmāṇḍāni$ in Łpāda$ a instead of Łbrahmāṇḍānāṃ$, but we should probably understand Łbrahmāṇḍānāṃ viśeṣān prasaṃkhyātuṃ...$ The structure noun in genitive + verb meaning 'telling' occurs also in 4.69a and \verify .
The claim that Brahmā taught Mātariśvan is confirmed in 1.64cd, and also, e.g., in \BrahmandaPur\ 3.4.58cd (see the apparatus).

My conjecture in Łpāda$ b (Łbhūbhṛtām$) is based on the fact that the readings transmitted in the MSS seem unintelligible and, more importantly, that these names are said to belong to Łnāyaka$s in the subsequent verses, a possible synonym of Łbhūbhṛt$ (`a king'), and also that it is a minute intervention. In Łpāda$ c, understand Łdiśāṣṭānāṃ$ as Łdiśām aṣṭānāṃ$ or Łdigaṣṭakānāṃ$, and note that one of the hallmarks of the language of the \VSS\ is the use of the singular in the proximity of numbers, where a plural would be expected (Łdaśa nāma$).

Note that many of the names here and in the following verses are, in the absence of any parallel passage, rather insecure. In order to avoid the repetition of the name Saha, I take the first name here as feminine; Asabhā seems also to be a feminine ruler's name. Later on there seem to come more feminine names (Tejā, Yamunā, Naganā, etc.), therefore it may be correct to interpret some of the names as names of queens. What is clear here is that the list evokes the name Sahasrākṣa, one of the appellations of Indra, the guadrian of the eastern direction.
Here, in the region of Agni, the names evidently evoke the image of flames.

I have choosen the variant Łsaṃyano$ in Łpāda$ c only to avoid the repetition of the name Łsaṃyama$, and the variant Łyanoyanaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d because I suspect that most of the names here should begin with Łya$. All the name forms in this verse are to be taken as tentative. The only guiding light is the presence of Łya$, reinforcing a connection with Yama.
Łnaga$ in Łpāda$ b is a stem form noun metri causa

Łtatparaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d might be another example of a singular form next to a number (see 1.40c above). Note that the reconstruction of these names are tentative. What is clear here is that the initials should be Łna$ and Łga$, probably suggesting a connection with Łnirṛti$, Łnaraka$s and Łnāga$s.
Varuṇa upholds the sky and the earth. This could be the reason why these names include Łbharaṇa$ and Łbhartṛ$.
The connection between Łvṛṣa$ and the north-west or Vāyu is not evident to me. \verify In a tantric context, a western position is more standard for Łvṛṣa$, see e.g. Pancavaranastava40.

I prefer the form Łsumanaḥ$ to the more standard Łsumanāḥ$ (\msNc) in Łpāda$ a, because it suits the slightly irregluar language of the \VSS\ (see pp. \verify), and because the solitary reading of \msNc\ may well only be an attempt to standardise. It is also not inconceivable that Łsumanaḥ$ stands compounded with Łsaumyaḥ$.

Note how Łdaśa nāyakam$ could again be an example for the use of the singular next to a number in Łpāda d$. It seems that here the northern region is associated with Śiva, rather than the north-east, the Łīśāna$ direction, which is occupied by Brahmā: see next verse. In a tantric context, Brahmā is sometimes associated with the north-east, see, e.g., Pancavaranastava39.\verify I have left Łsatya$ in stem form.
I consider Łindu, bindu$ and Łvajra$ stem form nouns.
The north-east seems to be occupied by Brahmā, and by rulers whose names should somehow evoke Brahmā's name.

Note that the last three lists above have been associated with Śiva, Brahmā and Viṣṇu, respectively, and here, in a layer of the text that can be labelled Vaṣṇava (see pp. \verify), it is Viṣṇu that seems to occupy a central position. Łmana mohanaḥ$ in Łpāda$ b may sound like one single name, but we are forced to separate these two words (Łmana$ being in stem form metri causa) to arrive at a list of ten names.

I take Łdaśa-m-īśānāṃ$ as a disjointed \verify\ compound (Łdaśeśānāṃ$). It is conceivable that each of the above ninety rulers has ten subordinates, therefore each group of ten rulers has a hundred subordinates altogether, but the original idea may have been that each one of the above ninety rulers has a hundred subordinates. Alternatively, this verse may only refer to the central group of ten rulers mentioned in 1.50, and each one of them has a hundred subordinates.

We are forced to follow \Ed's reading in Łpāda$ c in order to make sense of this passage. My correction in Łpāda$ d is motivated by the same. Note that Łvṛnda$ is not a number in this line. Elsewhere in this chapter Łvṛnda$ is the word that signifies `a billion'.
It seems that Łpāda$s ab repeat what has been stated in 1.52cd.
Łkoṭyena$ stands for Łkoṭyā$ (thematisation). Note how the scribe of \msM\ gets confused at 1.53c due to an eye-skip and fully regains control only at 1.55b.
Note that Łśaṅkubhiḥ$ stands for Łśaṅkūṣu$ (instrumental for locative).

ŁPāda$ a should probably be analysed and interpreted as Łpurāṇam (purāṇānām aśītisahasrāṇi śatāni ślokāni) brahmaṇā kathitam$. Alternatively, Łpāda$ a may have originally read Łpurāṇāni sahasrāṇi$, and then the inital number of verses transmitted by Brahmā is a hundred thousand. That the number refers to the number of Łśloka$s transmitted, and not, e.g., the number of lines, is confirmed in 1.66d: Łviṃśatślokasahasrikam$. On the idea that initially there was only one Purāṇa, see, e.g., RocherPuranas198641ff. In Łpāda$ d, either understand Łmātariśvā$ (nom.) as Łmātariśvānaṃ$ (acc.) or emend Łkathitaṃ$ to Łkathitaḥ$ in the sense `Mātariśvan was taught,' echoing 1.39cd: Łbrahmaṇā yat purākhyāto mātariśvā yathā tathā$. The list of Łvedavyāsa$s in \LinPu\ 1.7.15–18 includes these twenty-five names: Kratu, Satya, Bhārgava, Aṅgiras, Savitṛ, Mṛtyu, Śatakratu, Vasiṣṭha, Sārasvata, Tridhāman, Trivṛta, Śatatejas, Tarakṣu, Āruṇi, Kṛtaṃjaya, Ṛtaṃjayo, Bharadvāja, Gautama, Vācaśravas, Tṛṇabindu, Rūkṣa, Śakti, Jātūkarṇya, Kṛṣṇa Dvaipāyano.

Note the stem form noun Łpāda$ twice in this verse and the slightly odd grammatical structure (Łpurāṇaṃ$) Łprāptam uśanasam$ (`the Purāṇa reached Uśanas'), as opposed to the solution in Łpāda$ d (Łprāptavān$).
Note the odd structure in Łpāda$s ab: Łdhanaṃjayaḥ kṛtaṃjayāya samprāptaḥ$, for a more standard Łdhanaṃjayena (Łpurāṇam$) samprāpitaṃ kṛtaṃjayam$ (`the Purāṇa was transmitted to Kṛtaṃjaya').
The structure of Łpāda$s ab is as odd as that of 1.71ab. What was intended is probably Łṛṇañjayena prāpitaṃ gautamāya$.
My emendation in Łpāda$ d of Łharyadvatāya$ to Łharyātmanāya$ (for a standard Łharyātmane$) is based on the list of Łvedavyāsa$s in \VISNUP\ 3.3.16–17 (see note to 1.63 above).
The syntax is again slightly odd here. The indention may have been Łprāpitaṃ rājaśavasā somaśuṣmāya... tatas tṛṇabindunā prāptam$.
In other list of Łvedavyāsa$s, Tṛṇabindu hands the Purāṇas down to Ṛkṣa, Rūkṣa or Dakṣa (see note to 1.63 above). Łvṛkṣa$ in Łpāda$ a is probably a corrupted form.
The name Jatukarṇa may be a corrupted form of Jātū- or Jātukarṇa.
The syntax of Łpāda$s cd echoes that of 1.73ab above.

Romaharṣa is usually considered to be the same person as Sūta, disciple of Vyāsa Dvaipāyana. In \BrahmandaPur\ 3.4.67ab (Łmayā caitat{ }punaḥ proktaṃ putrāyāmitabuddhaye$, see note to 1.63 above) Amitabuddhi is clearly the name (or epithet) of Romaharṣa's son. This suggests that the form Łromaharṣāya$ in Łpāda$ a is a mistake for Łromaharṣaś ca$, or similar. MS \msM\ is either transmitting an otherwise syntactically problematic reading (Łromaharṣeṇa$) that is more original than that of most other witnesses or \msM's scribe is trying to correct the text. Supposing the former, in this case I accepted \msM's reading.

Manuscripts \msCc\ and \msM\ place the Łiti$ of the colophon at the end of the last Łśloka$, before the Łdaṇḍa$s, thus: Łicchasīti$ ||O|| (\msCc) and Łicchasi iti$ ||o|| (\msM). Note also that \msM\ gives the number of Łśloka$s in this chapter, 77, which is almost exactly the number of verses this critical edition has produced. The scribe of \msM\ struggled with eyeskips in this chapter, therefore it seems unlikely that he himself counted the number of verses he had copied and arrived at this very figure. Rather, he copied the number from his exemplar.
It is unlikely that Łjanāgreṇa$ picks up Łmayā$ (`by me, the best of men'), instead, I supposed that this instrumental stands for the ablative or should be understood as `through the best of man.'
The location where Śivāṇḍa was mentioned is verse 1.40ab above.

Łvā layanaṃ$ in Łpāda$ a may stand for Łvā-ālayanaṃ$, in the sense of Łvā-ālayaṃ$. The questions in this verse are most probably answered in verses 2.26–33, and if my interpretation is correct there, Łpramāṇaṃ vātra vāsinaḥ$ (understand Łvāsināṃ$) and Łpāda$ c should refer to the number of inhabitants in the five regions of Īśāna, Tatpuruṣa etc., who are refered to here in Łpāda$s a and possibly d.

My emendation to Łsamuddhṛtam$ in Łpāda$ b is not fully satisfactory, but the readings transmitted in the witnesses are problematic. \msM, a MS not collated for this chapter, gives a confusing reading: Łsamurdhnidam$. I doubt if \Ed's Łsamṛddhidam$ (`yielding success') is the correct reading. Perhaps Łsamudāhṛtam$ (`declared, talked about as') was meant. It is not inconceivable that \msCc's (and \msM's) Łagamyagahanaṃ$ (`it is inaccessible because of its depth') is original and it is to be contrasted with Łsamuddhṛtam$ (`lofty'). One also wonders if Łguhād$ could be the right reading, and in what sense, in Łpāda$ b.
Strictly speaking Łduḥśīlavān$ in Łpāda$ b is unmetrical; understand or pronounce Łduśīlavān$.
Łīrṣyatā$ (for Łīrṣyā$, see 2.7a) is a form rarely attested.
Łna sūyakaḥ$ in Łpāda$ b stands for Łna asūyaka$ metri causa.
Note the term Łanartī$ in Łpāda$ a: it might have something to do with non-material sacrifice (Łanarthayajña$), the topic of chapter 11. Łvraja$ in Łpāda$ a is suspect.
On Łmanvantara$s and Łkalpa$s, see 1.23–24 above.
Łāhūtasamplava$ for the more widely attested form Łābhūtasamplava$ occurs, e.g., in some MSS transmitting \SDHS\ 10.77 and 81 (see SDhS10_ed).

The phrase of Łtiryaṅnaraka$ appears in \MBH\ 3.181.18ab: Łaśubhaiḥ karmabhiḥ pāpās tiryaṅnarakagāminaḥ$. Here GanguliMBh translates Łtiryaṅ$ separately as `in a crooked way,' but I suspect that in the \VSS\ Łtiryannaraka$ has more to do with Łtiraggati$, being reduced to animal existence, being reborn as an animal or entering a hell in animal form. Cf. \MBH\ 13.134.057 (\verify): Łnṛṣu janma labhante ye karmaṇā madhyamāḥ smṛtāḥ | tiryaṅnarakagantāro hy adhamās te narādhamāḥ ||$, and ŁUmāmaheśvarasaṃvāda$ 6.1: Łavamanyanti ye viprān sarvaloke namaskṛtān | narakaṃ yānti te sarve tiryagyoniṃ vrajanti ca~||.$ I suspect that Łnātirya$ in the witnesses is only a scribal mistake for Łna tirya$.

lg.note: My translation of Łaiśvaryaguṇa$ is tentative. It could be taken as a Łdvandva$ compound (e.g. `supremacy and qualities'). The expression Łsarva$ or Łaṣṭaiśvaryaguṇopeta$ occurs frequently, e.g. in \SIVP\ 7.2.8.28ab and \SKANDAP\ 55.30cd, and \SDHU\ 2.6, 79, 125, 127, with Łaiśvarya$ most probably refering to the eight Łsiddhi$s Łaṇiman, laghiman$ etc. De Simini (2016a, 386),DeSiminiGods2016 e.g., translates Łsarvaiśvaryaguṇopetaḥ$ in \SDHU\ 2.127 as `endowed with all the qualities of lordship.'

listApp.note: Note the gender confusion in this verse, and the way I take Łpāda$ a as a separate statement to aviod a further confusion of case.

I understand Łpāda$ a as Łparārdhadviguṇa utsedho$, i.e. as an example of double Łsandhi$. On the other hand, Łsedho$ is only my conjecture, and may refer to something else than the Śivāṇḍa. Note the number confusion in Łpāda$ d, and also that two Łparārdha$s is one Łpara$, the highest possible number according to verses 1.35–36 above. The number may refer to any unit of length, but 2.23 below suggests that it is Łyojana$s.
Note that both Łanye$ and Łapare$ here pick up neuter nouns (gender confusion).
My conjectures in Łpāda$s ab result in a compoud split at the caesura, which may have been the reason why the line got corrupted.
I understand Łpāda$s cd, tentatively, as Łvikṣepaṃ parārdhadvayaṃ yojanānāṃ$
This line is a reply to 2.17b.

ŁPāda$ c is transmitted in an unmetrical form and with a gender problem in the witnesses (Łbhogam akṣayas$), hence my emendation using a stem form noun, a phenomenon frequently seen in this text. But note that Łbhoga$ is normally masculine; there might be a hiatus-filler in-between: Łbhoga-m-akṣaya$).

Note the stem form Łsmṛta$ in Łpāda$ d (cf. 2.29d). I understand Łīśānānāṃ$ as Łaiśānānāṃ$. Īśāna is traditionally the upward-looking face of Śiva, his region is positioned in the centre here. Note that the somewhat cryptic third Łpāda$s here and in the coming verses may or may not refer to the number of people living in the given region. They may tell us about the extent of the given region, although the numbers are much higher than what one would expect after verse 2.23.

The genitive of Łparārdhaparakoṭīnāṃ$ is baffling here and in the coming verses, but I suspect that again the expression gives the number of subjects living in the given region. Łpūrvasyāṃ$ is meant to mean Łpūrvāṃ$ (cf. Łdakṣiṇāṃ, paścimāṃ,$ and Łuttarāṃ$ in the next verses); note how \msNb\ tries to save the construction by reading Łdiśi$. This verse conforms to the traditional view that Śiva's Tatpuruṣa-face is looking to the east.
Note the Aiśa form Łdiśiṃ$ in \msCb, and that Aghora is indeed usually south-facing.

Note the Aiśa form Łdiśiṃ$ in \msNc\ in Łpāda$ b. In Łpāda$ d, we may presuppose the presence of a Łsandhi$-bridge: Łsadya-m-iṣṭālayaḥ$. Sadyojāta is traditionally associated with the western direction.
Note the Aiśa form Łdiśiṃ$ in \msCa\ in Łpāda$ b.
Vāmadeva is traditionally associated with the western direction.
Note how Łvaktrasya$ should refer to Śiva's Tatpuruṣa-face, given that the text lists Śiva's five faces: Īśāna, Tatpuruṣa, Aghora, Vāmadeva, Sadyojāta.
Note Łsadyaś$ in Łpāda$ a for Łsadyasaś$ or Łsadyojātasya$.
Łākṛṣṭyā$ in Łpāda$ a might be corrupt.
Understand Łkṛcchrāditapa sarvāṇi$ as Łkṛcchrāditapāṃsi sarvāṇi$. It can be considered an instance of the use of a stem form noun.

Notice the muta cum liquida licence in Łpāda$ a: Łsamapre$ renders as short-short-long. I take Łsamapreṣyena$ as if it read Łsampreṣito$, picking up Łdharmo$; otherwise it is difficult to make sense of it.

lg.note: As Kenji Takahashi pointed out to me, Fitzgerald_Alatacakra2012 is a good starting point to understand the implication of Łalātacakra$, `a single, rapidly twirled torch creat[ing] the illusion of an apparently real, continuous circle' (ibid., p. 777). The function of Łsarvaṃ$ in Łpāda$ a becomes clear only if we understand Łparibhraman$ in a causative sense (for Łparibhramayan$).

listApp.note: One cannot help noticing that this verse would be in a more fitting context after verse 1.31, at the end of a section on Łkāla$. On the other hand, it leads us to the next topic, Dharma, smoothly.

For the correct interpretation of Łpāda$ a, namely to decide whether these questions focus on the bull of Dharma or Dharma itself/himself, see the end of the previous chapter, where Łdharma$ was mentioned (2.40b), and to which the present verse is a reaction; see also \MBH\ 12.110.10–11: Łprabhāvārthāya bhūtānāṃ dharmapravacanaṃ kṛtam |
yat syād ahiṃsāsaṃyuktaṃ sa dharma iti niścayaḥ ||
dhāraṇād dharma ity āhur dharmeṇa vidhṛtāḥ prajāḥ |
yat syād dhāraṇasaṃyuktaṃ sa dharma iti niścayaḥ ||$ Note the similarities of \MBH\ this passage with this chapter: the phrase Łdharma ity āhur$, the fact that the present chapter from verse 18 on is actually a chapter on Łahiṃsā$, and that the etimological explanation involves the word [Łā$]Łdhāraṇa$ in both cases. These lead me to think that in Łpāda$s ab of this verse in the \VSS, it is Dharma that is the focus of the inquiry and not the bull.

Understand Łpāda$ d as Łgatayas tasya kati smṛtāḥ$. I have accepted Łsmṛtāḥ$ because this plural signals that Łgatis$ is meant to be plural, similarly to what happens in 3.6cd (Łtasya patnī... mahābhāgāḥ$). The use of the singular in a context of numbers and quantities is one of the hallmarks of the language of the \VSS, see p. \verify. On Dharma as a bull, see Introduction, pp. \verify.

lg.note: For similar Purāṇic passages on the etimology of Łdharma$, see the apparatus to this verse. The insertion in my translation '[of the same]' solves the problem of a noun (Łdhṛti$) seemingly being considered a verbal root (Łdhātu$) here. I owe thanks to Judit Törzsök for this interpretation. For similar passages with nominal stems appearently being treated as Łdhātu$s, see e.g. \VAYUP\ 3.17cd: Łbhāvya ity eṣa dhātur vai bhāvye kāle vibhāvyate$; \VAYUP\ 3.19cd (= \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 1.38.21ab): Łnātha ity eṣa dhātur vai dhātujñaiḥ pālane smṛtaḥ$; \LINPU\ 2.9.19: Łbhaja ity eṣa dhātur vai sevāyāṃ parikīrtitaḥ$

taṃ santo vidhivat{ }prāpya gacchanti paramāṃ gatim ||
gṛhebhya eva niṣkramya vanam{ }anye samāśritāḥ |

On the more frequently quoted interpretation of the four legs, see OlivelleAsrama235, a translation of \Manu\ 1.81–82: `Dharma and truth possess all four feet and are whole during the Kṛta yuga, and people did not obtain anything unrighteously (Ładharmeṇa$). By obtaining, however, Łdharma$ has lost one foot during each of the other Łyuga$s and righteousness (Łdharma$) likewise has diminished by one quarter due to theft, falsehood, and deceit. (MDh 1.81–82).' Understand Łpāda$s c and d as Łcatvāri āśramāṇi kīrtitāni dharmo manīṣibhiḥ$ or Łyo dharmaḥ kīrtitaś caturāśramāṇi manīṣibhiḥ$ or Łyo dharmaś caturāśramaḥ kīrtito manīṣibhiḥ$. Judit Törzsök suggested that Łcaturāśrama$ and Łdharmaḥ$ may be interpreted as a compound here.
Note the use of the singular next to numbers in Łpāda$ a, as in 3.1d, and that Łvijñeyāḥ$ is an emendation from Łvijñeyaḥ$ following the logic of 3.1d.
Łtirya$ seems to be an acceptable nominal stem in this text for Łtiryañc$. See, e.g., 4.6a: Łdevamānuṣatiryeṣu$. Łādayaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d seems superfluous.

Note the use of the singular in Łpāda$s cd. I have left Łsumadhyamāḥ$ as the manuscripts transmit it: it signals the presence of the plural. And consider correcting Łmahābhāgā$ to Łmahābhāgās$. In sum, understand Łtasya patnyo mahābhāgās trayodaśa sumadhyamāḥ$.

lg.note: Łśraddhāḍhyāḥ$ in Łpāda$ b is an attractive lectio difficilior (`they were rich in faith/devotion'), but I have finally decided to accept the easier and better-attested Łśraddhādyā$[Łḥ$]. Again, I have chosen/applied the plural forms Łādyāḥ$ and Łsumanoharāḥ$ in Łpāda$ b to hint at the fact that the presence of the plural is to be preferred here; thus only Łviśālākṣī$ is problematic. As Łpatnī$ in the previous verse, it should be treated as a plural. Note the use of the singular for the plural also in Łpāda$s cd, especially Łbabhūva ha$ for Łbabhūvuḥ$ (Łbabhūva ha$ perhaps being a phonetic and metrically `adjusted' equivalent, so to say, of Łbabhūvuḥ$).

listApp.note: I have emended Łtebhyaḥ$ to the correct feminine form Łtābhyaḥ$ because I suspect that it is only the result of some early confusion brought about by Łputras$, although Łtebhyaḥ$ might be original. Note again the use of the singular (nominative) for the plural (accusative) in Łpāda$s ab. Alternatively, emend Łdharmapatnī$ to Łdharmapatnīr$ (plural accusative) and Łputras$ to Łputrān$ to make them work with Łśrotum icchāmi$.

Note how Łlajjā$ in Łpāda$ b makes the line unumetrical. For Dharma's thirteen wives and their sons, see, e.g., \LINPU\ 1.5.34–37 (note the similarity between the first line and \VSS\ 3.6cd–7ab above): Łdharmasya patnyaḥ śraddhādyāḥ kīrtitā vai trayodaśa |
tāsu dharmaprajāṃ vakṣye yathākramam anuttamam ||
kāmo darpo 'tha niyamaḥ saṃtoṣo lobha eva ca |
śrutas tu daṇḍaḥ samayo bodhaś caiva mahādyutiḥ ||
apramādaś ca vinayo vyavasāyo dvijottamāḥ |
kṣemaṃ sukhaṃ yaśaś caiva dharmaputrāś ca tāsu vai ||
dharmasya vai kriyāyāṃ tu daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca |
apramādas tathā bodho buddher dharmasya tau sutau ||$.

Łprasūtisambhavāḥ$ in Łpāda$ d is a rather bold conjecture that can be supported by two facts: firstly, the readings of the manuscripts are difficult to make sense of and thus are probably corrupt; secondly, a corruption from the name Prasūti, traditionally the name of Dakṣa's wife, to Łābhūti$ is relatively easily to explain, Łsū$ and Łbhū$ being close enough in some scripts (e.g. in \msCa) to cause confusion. Another option would be to accept Ābhūti as the name of Dakṣa's wife. For Prasūti being Dakṣa's wife in other sources, see, e.g., \LINPU\ 1.5.20–21 (but also note the presence of the name Sambhūti): Łprasūtiḥ suṣuve dakṣāc caturviṃśatikanyakāḥ | śraddhāṃ lakṣmīṃ dhṛtiṃ puṣṭiṃ tuṣṭiṃ medhāṃ kriyāṃ tathā || buddhi lajjāṃ vapuḥ śāntiṃ siddhiṃ kīrtiṃ mahātapāḥ | khyātiṃ śāntiś ca saṃbhūtiṃ smṛtiṃ prītiṃ kṣamāṃ tathā ||$.
Understand Łśraddhā$ as a stem form noun for Łśraddhāyāḥ$ (gen./abl., cf. 3.11a). Alternatively, take Łśraddhā$ and Łsuto$ as elements of a split compound, and understand Łśraddhāsuto jātaḥ kāmaḥ$.

I have emended Łabhayaḥ$ to Łabhavat$ in Łpāda$ c, following the relevant line in the \KURMP\ cited above (Łkriyāyāś cābhavat putro daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca$) and also \LINPU\ 1.5.37 quoted in the apparatus to this verse, allotting only two sons to Kriyā. Thus I don't think that Kriyā is supposed to have a son called Abhaya (`Freedom from danger'; \BHAGP\ 4.1.50ab claims that Dayā had a son called Abhaya: Łśraddhāsūta śubhaṃ maitrī prasādam abhayaṃ dayā$). Nevertheless, in a number of sources Kriyā actually has three sons, see, e.g., \VISNUP\ 1.7.26ab, where they are named as Daṇḍa, Naya and Vinaya: Łmedhā śrutaṃ kriyā daṇḍaṃ nayaṃ vinayam eva ca$. Perhaps read Łkriyāyās tu nayaḥ putro$ in Łpāda$ c? Compare \VAYUP\ 1.10.34cd (Łkriyāyās tu nayaḥ prokto daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca$) with \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 1.9.60ab (Łkriyāyās tanayau proktau damaś ca śama eva ca$).

In a very similar passages in \KURMP\ 1.8.20 ff., Apramāda is Buddhi's son and Lajjā has only one son, Vinaya. In the above verse (\VSS\ 3.12), Łsudhiyaḥ$ (for Łsudhīḥ$) may only be qualifying Łapramāda$, thus Lajjā may have two sons: Vinaya and the wise Apramāda. Alternatively, Łpāda$s cd might be a extra line inserted accidentally.

Note that Łsukhaṃ$ in Łpāda$ d is probably meant to be masculine (Łsukhaḥ$), but e.g. in the \KURMP\ passage quoted above it is also neuter. For the emendation in Łpāda$ e, see \MATSP\ 9.2cd: Łyāmā nāma purā devā āsan svāyambhuvāntare$, and \BHAGP\ 6.4.1: Łdevāsuranṛṇāṃ sargo nāgānāṃ mṛgapakṣiṇām | sāmāsikas tvayā prokto yas tu svāyambhuve 'ntare ||$.

Note Łdharma$ as a neuter noun and the form Łatīvaṃ$ for Łatīva$ metri causa. My emen\-dation from Łkīrtaya$ (`declare') to Łkartaya$ (`cut') was influenced by the combination of Łchindhi$ and Łsaṃśaya$, often with Łkautūhala$, elsewhere in the \VSS: 3.2ab: Łkautūhalaṃ mamotpannaṃ saṃśayaṃ chindhi tattvataḥ$; 10.10cd: Łkautūhalaṃ mahaj jātaṃ chindhi saṃśayakārakam$; 15.2ab: Łetat kautūhalaṃ chindhi saṃśayaṃ parameśvara$. The reading Łkīrtaya$ may have been the result of the influence of Łkīrtitā$ in 3.13b above (De Simini's observation).

The reading Łdvayī$ in \msNc\ in Łpāda$ a is attractive, but as Judit Törzsök has pointed out to me, it is more likely that the slightly less convincing but widespread variant Łdvayor$ is original. As for Dharma being based on Łśruti$ and Łsmṛti$, see, e.g., \Manu\ 2.10: Łśrutis tu vedo vijñeyo dharmaśāstraṃ tu vai smṛtiḥ | te sarvārtheṣv amīmāṃsye tābhyāṃ dharmo hi nirbabhau ||$. In Olivelle's translation (OlivelleManu94): `\thinspace ``Scripture'' should be recognized as ``Veda,'' and ``tradition'' as ``Law Treatise.'' These two should never be called into question in any matter, for it is from them that the Law shines forth.'

There may be a hiatus filler in Łpāda$s cd: Łsambandha-m-ijyā$ for Łsambandha ijyā$. To state that the Smārta tradition is connected to Łyama$s and Łniyama$s and the Łāśrama$s and then to discuss these at length (principally in chapters 3–8 and 11) can be seen as a clear self-identification with the Smārta tradition.
ŁPāda$ a should be understood as Łyamaniyamayoś caiva$, but the author of this line may have tried to avoid the metrical fault of having two short syllables in the second and third positions.

Note that this is the beginning of a long section in our text that describes the Łyama-niyama$ rules, reaching up to the end of chapter eight. The title given in the colophon of the next chapter, chapter four, namely Łyamavibhāga$, would fit this locus better than the beginning of that chapter, which commences with a discussion on the second of the Łyama$s, Łsatya$.
Note how all witnesses read Łmādhūrya$ in Łpāda$ e instead of Łmādhurya$. The former may have been acceptable originally in this text. ŁPāda$ e is a Łma-vipulā$.
In Łpāda$ a, Łpañca$ and Łbheda$ may be typeset as two separate words since the use of the singular after numbers is one of the hallmarks of the text (see \verify).

Note the use of the singular in Łpāda$s cd referring back to the agents of the previous sentence. Most probably, Łvadhyam$ is to be understand as Łvadham$ and the form Łvadhyam$ serves only to avoid two Łlaghu$ syllables in Łpāda$ d.

Understand Łbhujoraś ca$ in Łpāda$ a as Łbhuje, urasi ca$, in this case with an instance of double sandhi, and in stem form: Łbhuje urasi ca$ \rightarrow\ Łbhuja urasi ca$ \rightarrow\ Łbhujorasi ca$ \rightarrow\ Łbhujoraś ca$. Alternatively, understand it as a compound (Łbhujorasi$). In Łpāda$ b, my emendation is only one of the possible interpretations. We might accept Łśiroru$ as consisting of Łśira$ + Łūru$ (`head and thigh'), or emend it to Łśiroraḥ$ for Łśira$ + Łuraḥ$ (`head and chest'). Also note my conjecture in Łpāda$ d, without which this Łpāda$ is difficult to interpret.
Understand Łvadhaḥ$ in Łpāda$ b as Łvadhyaḥ$ metri causa.
My translation of the second line of this verse reflects a conjecture (Łtaddvārā$) understood as connected to both Łpāda$ c and Łnihataḥ$ in Łpāda$ d.

ŁPāda$ a is unmetrical. Note how elliptical this verse is and that Łhiṃsakāni$ is neuter although it refers to people, perhaps implying Łbhūtāni$. Alternatively, take Ły$ in Łhiṃsakāny$ as a rather unusual sandhi-bridge (Łhiṃsakān-y-āhu$), or simply delete this Ły$. Note also that Łāhu$ stands for Łāhur$ metri causa.

lg.note: Note Łdharma$ as a neuter noun in Łpāda$ a and that Łvinirmuktaṃ$ and Łpradam$ are neuter accordingly.

Note that Łparataro$ is masculine in Łpāda$ d, picking up a neuter Ł'yaśaḥ$. This phenomenon is probably the result of Ł'yaśaḥ$ resembling a masculine noun ending in Ł-aḥ$ and also of the metrical problem with a grammatically correct Łnātaḥ parataram ayaśaḥ$.

listApp.note: ŁPāda$ d (Łnātaḥ paraṃ tapodhana$) is slightly suspect. The vocative Łtapodhana$ usually refers to Anarthayajña in these passages, and not to Vigatarāga, as here. The text may have read Łnātaḥ paratamo 'dhanaḥ$ (`There is no bigger loss of wealth') or possibly something starting with Łnātaḥ paraṃ tapo ...$ (`There is no greater\dots\ of austerity').
See \UUMS\ chapter two for a similar section on meat-consumption.

See a similarly phrased comparison in \Manu\ 2.86: Łye pākayajñās catvāro vidhiyajñasamanvitāḥ |
sarve te japayajñasya kalāṃ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīm ||$.
Understand Łphalam āhārā$ as Łphalāhārā$ (Ł-m-$ is a sandhi-bridge).
This verse clearly refers to the story of the ŁRāmāyaṇa$.

Łguṇākāśāt$ in pāda c is difficult to interpret and Łguṇākarṣāt$ is a conjecture by Judit Törzsök which fits the context well, although the polysemy of Łguṇa$ may allow for other solutions. Verses 3.40–42 may be echoing \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 216.64–66: Ł māṃsān miṣṭataraṃ nāsti bhakṣyabhojyādikeṣu ca |
tasmān māṃsaṃ na bhuñjīta nāsti miṣṭaiḥ sukhodayaḥ ||
gosahasraṃ tu yo dadyād yas tu māṃsaṃ na bhakṣayet |
samāv etau purā prāha brahmā vedavidāṃ varaḥ ||
sarvatīrtheṣu yat puṇyaṃ sarvayajñeṣu yat phalam |
amāṃsabhakṣaṇe viprās tac ca tac ca ca tatsamam ||$.

ŁPāda$s ab are reminescent of \SDHS\ 11.92: Łahiṃsaikā paro dharmaḥ śaktānāṃ parikīrtitam |
aśaktānām ayaṃ dharmo dānayajñādipūrvakaḥ ||$. On this verse see also SaivaUtopia202115–16. Note the variant Łdharma$ in both \msCc\ and \Ed\ in Łpāda$ b.

lg.l: tīrthānāṃ ca sahasrakoṭiniyutaṃ snātvā sakṛn mānavaḥ

listApp.note: Metre: Łśārdūlavikrīḍita$. On Łpadma$ meaning `ten trillion', and on other words for numbers, see 1.32–35. Łkoṭīyajña$ in Łpāda$ d may refer to a special kind of sacrifice, mostly known as Łkoṭihoma$ in the Purāṇas and in inscriptions (see, e.g., Fleming2010and 2013Fleming2013) It probably involves a hundred fire-pits and a hundred times one thousand Brahmins (hence the name `the ten-million sacrifice'). See, e.g., \BHAVP\ Łuttaraparvan$ 4.142.54–58: Łśatānano daśamukho dvimukhaikamukhas tathā | caturvidho mahārāja koṭihomo vidhīyate || kāryasya gurutāṃ jñātvā naiva kuryād aparvaṇi | yathā saṃkṣepataḥ kāryaḥ koṭihomas tathā śṛṇu || kṛtvā kuṇḍaśataṃ divyaṃ yathoktaṃ hastasaṃmitam | ekaikasmiṃs tataḥ kuṇḍe śataṃ viprān niyojayet || sadyaḥ pakṣe tu viprāṇāṃ sahasraṃ parikīrtitam | ekasthānapraṇīte 'gnau sarvataḥ paribhāvite || homaṃ kuryur dvijāḥ sarve kuṇḍe kuṇḍe yathoditam | yathā kuṇḍabahutve 'pi rājasūye mahākratau || $ Note that the second syllable of Łphalam$ in Łpāda$ d is treated as long: this happens often at word-boundaries in this text; and note how \msNc\ aims to restore the metre by inserting Łtv$ after its Łphalaṃ$.

Although the rather similar line in the \SDHS\ (11.105cd: Łyathābhūtārthakathanam ity etat satyalakṣaṇam$) makes it tempting to emend Łsatyakathanaṃ$ to Łsatyalakṣaṇaṃ$ in Łpāda$ d, I rather take this verse to introduce two views on truth: one philosophical, and one ordinary that relates to the moral question of truthfulness.
Łsuduḥsaham$ (singular) in Łpāda$ b picks up Łādīni$ (plural) in Łpāda$ a. The Ł-m$ in Łsatyam$ may be a sandhi-bridge and the phrase may refer to a masculine subject thus: Łsa ca satya-m-udāhṛtaḥ$.
Understand Łudyataḥ$ (nom.) in an active sense (`holding/lifting').

lg.note: This Łupajāti$ verse appears in countless sources, beginning with the \MBH\ (see the apparatus). All versions contain a vocative addressing a king, which is out of context in the \VSS, the addressee being Vigatarāga, i.e. Viṣṇu diguised as a Brahmin. The redactors did not notice or did not care about this small inconsistency. Note the metrical licence that allows the last syllable of Łyuktam$ to count as long. The same reading with Łanṛtaṃ$ can be found in the apparatus in the \MBH\ critical edition.

listApp.note: ŁPāda$ d is slightly problematic because it is difficult to ascertain if some of the MSS actually read Łpanthāna$ or Łpasthāna$ (or Łyasthāna$). I suspect that Łpanthāna$ is a stem form noun formed (metri causa) to stand for an irregular nominative of Łpathin$.
The repetition of Łtīrthaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c is sightly suspect. Cf., e.g., \MATSP\ 22.79ab: Łsatyaṃ tīrthaṃ dayā tīrthaṃ tīrtham{ }indriyanigrahaḥ$.
Looking at the similar line in the \VARP\ (193.36cd, see the apparatus), one wonders if the slightly odd Łūrdhvasya$ in Łpāda$ c is not a corrupt form of Łsvargasya$.
Here and several times below, Łsatye$ is probably to be taken as standing for Łsatyena$.

ŁPāda$ b, Łsamayena priyavrataḥ$, probably stand for Łsamayena priyavratasya$ although it is unclear to me what exactly Łsamaya$ refers to here. For the story of Priyavrata, Manu's son, in which he wanted to turn nights into days by circling aroung Mount Meru in a chariot, and by this produced the seven oceans, see, e.g., \BHAGP\ 5.1.30–31:
Łyāvad avabhāsayati suragirim anuparikrāman bhagavān ādityo vasudhātalam ardhenaiva pratapaty ardhenāvacchādayati, tadā hi [priyavrataḥ] bhagavadupāsanopacitātipuruṣaprabhāvas tad anabhinandan samajavena rathena jyotirmayena rajanīm api dinaṃ kariṣyāmīti saptakṛtvas taraṇim anuparyakrāmad dvitīya iva pataṅgaḥ | ye vā u ha tadrathacaraṇanemikṛtaparikhātās te sapta sindhava āsan yata eva kṛtāḥ sapta bhuvo dvīpāḥ |$.

lg.note: ŁPāda$s cd: for a somewhat similar reference to the story of Mahābali, see, e.g., \VAMP\ 65.66: Łevaṃ purā cakradhareṇa viṣṇunā baddho balir vāmanarūpadhāriṇā | śakrapriyārthaṃ surakāryasiddhaye hitāya viprarṣabhagodvijānām ||$

listApp.note: Since Łśaśi$ (instead of Łśaśin$) is a possible stem in this text, Łśaśir ācaraḥ$ could be acceptable here in Łpāda$ b (see \msNa\msNb\msNc), perhaps standing for Łśaśinaś caraṇam$ or Łśaśiś carati$. My conjecture (Łśaśinā caraḥ$) could stand for Łśaśinā/śaśinaś cāraḥ$ metri causa. Other possibilities, suggested by colleagues, include Łśaśibhāskaraḥ$, Łśaśigocaraḥ$ and Łśiśirāmbhasaḥ$.

ŁPāda$s cd refer to the story of Agastya and the Vindhya mountain: Vindhya became jealous of the Sun's revolving around Mount Meru and when the Sun refused him the same favour, he decided to grow higher and obstruct the Sun's movement. As a solution to this situation, Agastya asked Vidhya to bend down to make it easier for him to reach the south and to remain thus until he retured. Vindhya agreed to do what Agastya asked him but Agastya never returned. See \MBH\ 3.102.1–14 (see in the word Łsamaya$ in verse 13 and compare it to \VSS\ 4.12b): Ł yudhiṣṭhira uvāca |
kimarthaṃ sahasā vindhyaḥ pravṛddhaḥ krodhamūrchitaḥ |
etad icchāmy ahaṃ śrotuṃ vistareṇa mahāmune ||
lomaśa uvāca |
adrirājaṃ mahāśailaṃ meruṃ kanakaparvatam |
udayāstamaye bhānuḥ pradakṣiṇam avartata ||
taṃ tu dṛṣṭvā tathā vindhyaḥ śailaḥ sūryam athābravīt |
yathā hi merur bhavatā nityaśaḥ parigamyate ||
pradakṣiṇaṃ ca kriyate mām evaṃ kuru bhāskara |
evam uktas tataḥ sūryaḥ śailendraṃ pratyabhāṣata ||
nāham ātmecchayā śaila karomy enaṃ pradakṣiṇam |
eṣa mārgaḥ pradiṣṭo me yenedaṃ nirmitaṃ jagat ||
evam uktas tataḥ krodhāt pravṛddhaḥ sahasācalaḥ |
sūryācandramasor mārgaṃ roddhum icchan paraṃtapa ||
tato devāḥ sahitāḥ sarva eva; sendrāḥ samāgamya mahādrirājam |
nivārayām āsur upāyatas taṃ; na ca sma teṣāṃ vacanaṃ cakāra ||
athābhijagmur munim āśramasthaṃ; tapasvinaṃ dharmabhṛtāṃ variṣṭham |
agastyam atyadbhutavīryadīptaṃ; taṃ cārtham ūcuḥ sahitāḥ surās te ||
devā ūcuḥ |
sūryācandramasor mārgaṃ nakṣatrāṇāṃ gatiṃ tathā |
śailarājo vṛṇoty eṣa vindhyaḥ krodhavaśānugaḥ ||
taṃ nivārayituṃ śakto nānyaḥ kaś cid dvijottama |
ṛte tvāṃ hi mahābhāga tasmād enaṃ nivāraya ||
lomaśa uvāca |
tac chrutvā vacanaṃ vipraḥ surāṇāṃ śailam abhyagāt |
so 'bhigamyābravīd vindhyaṃ sadāraḥ samupasthitaḥ ||
mārgam icchāmy ahaṃ dattaṃ bhavatā parvatottama |
dakṣiṇām abhigantāsmi diśaṃ kāryeṇa kena cit ||
yāvadāgamanaṃ mahyaṃ tāvat tvaṃ pratipālaya |
nivṛtte mayi śailendra tato vardhasva kāmataḥ ||
evaṃ sa samayaṃ kṛtvā vindhyenāmitrakarśana |
adyāpi dakṣiṇād deśād vāruṇir na nivartate ||
etat te sarvam ākhyātaṃ yathā vindhyo na vardhate |
agastyasya prabhāvena yan māṃ tvaṃ paripṛcchasi ||$.
Łsatye$ in Łpāda$ c may stand for Łsatyaṃ$: `The soul dwells in the body as truth.'
Or: `If truth alone (Łekena$) is obtained, Dharma is surely accomplished.'
It is not inconceivable that Łtava$ is meant to carry the sense of the ablative, as Kenji Takahashi has suggested to me: `I can't have enough of learning about Dharma from you.'
`Theft' (Ładattādāna$): literally `taking what has not been given.'
My impression is that Łprabhāva$ in Łpāda$ a stands for Łbhāva$, Łduṣṭabhāva$ (`vicious') being a common expression.
The implications of Łvāryamāṇo$ in Łpāda$ c are unclear to me, hence my emendation to Łvāryamāṇā$. My translation is thus tentative and still not satisfactory.

Note that Łmūlyaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c is a conjecture for Łmūla$. It is partly based on a relevant passage in the \Mitaksara\ (ad \YajnS\ 2.176cd): Łpaṇyasya krītadravyasya yan mūlyaṃ dattam, bhṛtir vetanaṃ kṛtakarmaṇe dattam\dots\ utkocena kāryapratibandhanirāsārtham adhikṛtebhyo dattam$\dots\

Note Łasau$ in Łpāda$ e as an accusative form (for Łamum$ or Ładaḥ$). It is not unlikely that Łtena$ is a corruption from Łstena$, and the Łpāda$ may have originally read Łstenaṃ taṃ ca vijānīyād$ (`he should be known as a thief'), or similar (cf. 4.22c below). \msM\ (f. 7r) reads Łtena steya vijānīyād$ here.
A line may have dropped out after Łpāda$ b, perhaps because a line similar to 4.22cd caused an eyeskip. Alternatively, this line may simply be elliptical.
It is possible that Łpāda$ d read differently, e.g. Łsa coraś cora ucyate$, meaning `that thief is [rightly] called a thief'.
Note the peculiar sandhi in Łpāda$ c (Łsama ajño$), which still leaves the Łpāda$ unmetrical.

Note how Łstena$ and Łsteya$ are used interchangeably (or chaotically) in the above passages in the MSS to denote both `thief' and 'theft/stealing'. The scribe of \msNc\ ends up writing Łstenya$ in 4.27e.

lg.l: pracchanno hriyate 'rtham anyapuruṣaḥ pratyakṣam anyo haret

listApp.note: Metre Łśārdūlavikrīḍita$. It appears that Łhriyate$ in Łpāda$ a is to be taken as an active verb (Łharate$). Note also how \msCb\ and \msNc\ read the same here against the other witnesses.
Take Łhariṇo$ in Łpāda$ b as singular and Łm$ in Ł'nya-m-adhamo$ as a sandhi-bridge. Alternatively, read as plural: Łhariṇo 'nya adhamo$\dots\
The second half of Łpāda$ c is difficult to reconstruct.

lg.l: anyaḥ krītadhano 'paro dhayahṛta ete jaghanyāḥ smṛtāḥ

listApp.note: The translation of Łpāda$ d is mostly guesswork. Tentatively, I take Łkrīta$ as Łkrītaka$ (`a purchased son', see \Manu\ 9.174). Łdhayahṛta$ makes little sense to me. Florinda De Simini suggested that Łdhaya$ might stand for Łdaya$, which in turn may stand for Łdāya$ (`inheritance') metri causa. Lacking any better solution, I supplied these in my translation, marked with question marks. Note also the metrical licence that the last syllable of Łdhayahṛta$ counts as long.

lg.l: stenatulya na mūḍham asti puruṣo dharmārthahīno 'dhamaḥ

listApp.note: For some time I was wondering if one should accept \Ed's reading Łstenastulya na mūḍham asti$ as a metri causa version of Łstenatulyo na mūḍho 'sti$; see a similar case of a nominative ending inside of compound in Łpāda$ c below. One major concern remained: the accepted reading would be of an edition that rarely emerges as the sole transmitter of the best reading. Another possible solution could be to emend to Łstenaṃtulya$\dots, meaning `There is no bigger foolishness than theft', but then the second part of Łpāda$ a is difficult to connect. In the end, I decided to to go for the most widely attested reading (Łstenatulya$), which is unmetrical.

lg.l: yāvaj jīvati śaṅkayā narapateḥ saṃtrasyamāno raṭan

listApp.note: Understand Łprāptaḥśāsana tīvrasahyaviṣamaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c as Łprāptaśāsanas tīvram asahyaṃ ca viṣamaṃ prāpnoti$. Alternatively, understand Łtīvrasahya$ as Łduḥsahya$ (suggested by Törzsök). The actual reading of \msCa, Łprāptaś$ (lost in the process of normalization and standing in contrast with that of all other MSS that read Łprāptaḥ$) may suggest a doubling of the Łś$ of Łśāsana$ metri causa (suggestion by Törzsök). More likely is that a licence of having a nominative ending inside of a compound is applied here, as may have been the case above in Łpāda$ a (also remarked by Törzsök).

lg.l: kālena mriyate sa yāti nirayam ākrandamāno bhṛśam
nītvā durgatikoṭikalpa nirayāt tiryatvam āyānti te

listApp.note: Note the stem form Łkalpa$ for Łkalpaṃ$ metri causa.

lg.l: tiryatve ca tathaivam ekaśatikaṃ prabhramya varṣārbudam

listApp.note: In Łpāda$ c, Łtathaivam$, or Łtathaikam$, and Łekaśatikaṃ$ are suspect.

I understand Łvipule$ as Łvipulāyāṃ$, Łvipulā$ appearing in \Amara\ 2.1.7 as a synonym of Łdhātrī$, `earth' because it is difficult to interpret it otherwise. This is still problematic because both human and animal existence takes place on earth, thus, if Łtiryatva$ (i.e. Łtiryaktva$) indeed means `animal existence,' there is no contrast between Łpāda$s b and c as regards location. As for Łtiryaktva$, see, e.g., \Manu\ 12.40: Łdevatvaṃ sāttvikā yānti manuṣyatvaṃ ca rājasāḥ | tiryaktvaṃ tāmasā nityam ity eṣā trividhā gatiḥ ||$ It is not unlikely that the original form of Łdāridryarogākulam$ was Łdāridryarogākule$, picking up Łvipule$.

lg.l: tasmād durgatihetu karma sakalaṃ tyaktvā śivaṃ cāśrayet

listApp.note: Note the switch from plural to singular in Łpāda$ d.
Note Łpitur$ and Łmātur$ used as accusative forms in Łpāda$ b, or alternatively understand: `who are hateful towards their fathers and mothers'.

Törzsök has suggested emending Łsa nṛśaṃsakaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d to Łtannṛṃśakaḥ$. I don't think that it is inevitably necessary. I think that Łpāda$s a-c form a list that is meant to be in the genitive, understanding \dots\ Łity eteṣāṃ dūṣakaḥ sa nṛśaṃsakaḥ$ or similar. This is clumsy but in a way that is more than possible within the style of this text. I have not been able find any attestation of Łvyoman$ meaning the five elements. Perhaps it is meant to mean Łvyomādi$ (`the atmosphere/sky and the other four elements'). For Śiva of eight forms, see, e.g., ŁŚakuntalā$ 1.1: Łyā sṛṣṭiḥ sraṣṭur ādyā [1] vahati vidhihutaṃ yā havir [2] yā ca hotrī [3]
ye dve kālaṃ vidhattaḥ [4,5] śruti-viṣaya-guṇā yā [6] sthitā vyāpya viśvam |
yām āhuḥ sarva-bīja-prakṛtir [7] iti yayā prāṇinaḥ prāṇavantaḥ [8]
pratyakṣābhiḥ prapannas tanubhir avatu vas tābhir aṣṭābhir īśaḥ ||$.
The eight Łmūrti$s, or rather, Łtanu$s, here are: [1] Łjala$ [2] Łagni$ [3] Łyajamāna$ [4,5] Łsūrya$ + Łcandra$ [6] Łākāśa$ [7] Łbhūmi$ [8] Łvāyu$. For a similar interpretation of Łaṣṭamūrti$, see, e.g., ŁĪśānaśivagurudevapaddhati$ 2.29.34 (Łmantrapāda$; note Łyajamāna$ for our Łdīkṣa$): Łkṣmā-vahni-yajamānārka-jala-vāyv-indu-puṣkaraiḥ$ | Łaṣṭābhir mūrtibhiḥ śambhor dvitīyāvaraṇaṃ smṛtam$ || (For Łpuṣkara$ as `sky, atmosphere', see, e.g., \Amara\ 1.2.167: Łdyodivau dve striyām abhraṃ vyoma puṣkaram ambaram$.) A closely related Aṣṭamūrti-hymn appears in \Nisvmukh\ 1.30–41 (I owe thanks to Nirajan Kafle for drawing my attention to this); see KafleNisvasaBook62, 63, 116, 119. Kafle notes that this hymn is closely parallel to some passages in the ŁPrayogamañjarī$ (1.19–26), the ŁTantrasamuccaya$ (1.16–23), and the ŁĪśānaśivagurudevapaddhati$ (Łkriyāpāda$ 26.56–63). See also \TAKI\ s.v. Łaṣṭamūrti$.

It is difficult to restore Łpāda$s cd, although the general meaning of this line is predictable. Some questions remain. Is Łāditya$ a good reading or is Łmātṛ$ hidden in Łdaivata-mādiśca$? Is Łānṛśaṃsa$ right or was it Łnṛśaṃsa$ that was meant by the author of this line? Does Łtamanvitaḥ$ (or Łtamānvitaḥ$) has anything to do with Łtamas$ (`darkness')?
The use of Łkarsaṇa$ in Łpāda$ d, most probably in the sense of `collecting,' is slightly odd.
The five Pavitras are most probably the five Łbrahmamantras$, see, e.g., \TAKIII\ s.v. Łpavitra$ 1.

lg.l: gobhir na tulyaṃ dhanam asti kiṃcid
lg.note: Note that Łduhyanti$ and Łvāhyanti$ are supposed to be understood as passive, as in the similar verse in \SDHU\ 12.92 (see apparatus).

listApp.note: Strictly speaking, Łpāda$ c is unmetrical. The second syllable of Łtapa$ counts as long (see Intro \verify).

My conjecture in Łpāda$ a (Łpātreṇa$ for Łpādyena$) was inspired by the fact that Łpāda$ b seems to awkwardly repeat what Łpādyena$ in Łpāda$ a signifies. Other possibilities could include taking into account bathing (Łsnāna$) or an unguent (Łabhyaṅga$).

For the requirement that one could part with his wife or son, or his own life, for the benefit of someone else, see \VSS\ 2.38 and the narrative in \VSS\ chapter 12 which tells about a Brahmin giving away his own wife to a guest; these influenced my decision to emend Łātmano$ to Łātmanā$ in Łpāda$ a. Note that in fact \VSS\ 4.44cd below echoes verse 37cd in the above mentioned chapter 12: Łdvijarūpadharo dharmaḥ svayam eva ihāgataḥ$.

lg.note:
The demonstrative pronoun Łtasya$ in Łpāda$ c may refer to the guest: `he will obtain all his [i.e. the guest's] merits,' hinting at some sort of karmic exchange. Nevertheless, I think rather that Łtasya$ points to the merits one can obtain by the rituals listed in the previous verse. This is suggested by passages such as the following: \MBH\ Supp. 13.14.379 ff.:
Łahany ahani yo dadyāt kapilāṃ dvādaśīḥ samāḥi |
māsi māsi ca satreṇa yo yajeta sadā naraḥ ||
gavāṃ śatasahasraṃ ca yo dadyāj jyeṣṭhapuṣkare |
na taddharmaphalaṃ tulyam atithir yasya tuṣyati ||$ \BRAHMAVP\ 3.44–46:
Łatithiḥ pūjito yena pūjitāḥ sarvadevatāḥ |
atithir yasya saṃtuṣṭas tasya tuṣṭo hariḥ svayam ||
snānena sarvatīrtheṣu sarvadānena yat phalam |
sarvavratopavāsena sarvayajñeṣu dīkṣayā ||
sarvais tapobhir vividhair nityair naimittikādibhiḥ |
tad evātithisevāyāḥ kalāṃ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīm ||$.

listApp.note: Something has gone wrong with Łpāda$s ab and I am unable to reconstruct the meaning. The line may have begun with something like Łnāgatātithyavajña$ (`he who despise a guest that has arrived will not\dots').

This verse is a reference to the story related by a mongoose in \MBH\ 14.92–93: A Brahmin who practises the vow of gleaning (Łuñcha$) and his family receive a guest. They feed the guest with the last morsels of the little food they have. In the end, the guest reveals that he is in fact Dharma (14.93.80cd) and as a reward the family departs to heaven. The noble act of the poor Brahmin and his family is depicted as yielding greater rewards than Yudhiṣṭhira's grandiose horse-sacrifice. (See some remarks on this story in TakahashiUnca.)

We would be forced to accept the reading of \Ed\ in Łpāda$ d (Łsaśarīro$) if the expression were in the masculine (Łdivaṃ gataḥ$). This would make sense and it would also echo expressions occuring, e.g., in the \MBH: 3.164.33cd: Łpaśya puṇyakṛtāṃ lokān saśarīro divaṃ vraja$; 14.5.10cd: Łsaṃjīvya kālam iṣṭaṃ ca saśarīro divaṃ gataḥ$. It is tempting to emend accordingly, but instead I have retained Łsvaśarīraṃ divaṃ gatam$, and I interpret it in a general way.

I suspect that the final Łm$ in Łdhamahīnam$ in Łpāda$ c is a hiatus filler: Łdhamahīna-m-adharmaś ca$. Łkāmakulapradaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d is suspect, and my translation is unsatisfactory. This compound could be interpreted as `fullfilling desires and giving a family' or it may have originally read Łsarvakāmapradaḥ$ (`fullfilling all desires') or Łkulakāmapradaḥ$ (`fullfilling the desires of the family'). \SDHS\ 4.28b reads Łsarvakāmasukhapradam$, which opens up further possibilities.
Note Łkari$ for Łkarī$ metri causa, and the end of Łpāda$ b (Łmṛgāḥ$), which should be treated metrically as if it read Łmrigāḥ$.
The only way to make sense of Łpāda$s cd is to supply and Łavagraha$ before Łsamyag$. Otherwise some text may have dropped out here.
My comments in square brackets in the translation are tentative.

ŁMātaṅgalīlā$ 11.1 may shed some light on elephants dying in captivity: Łvānyas tatra sukhoṣitā vidhivaśād grāmāvatīrṇā gajā baddhās tīkṣṇakaṭūgravāgbhir atiśugbhīmohabandhādibhiḥ | udvignāś ca manaḥśarīrajanitair duḥkhair atīvākṣamāḥ prāṇān dhārayituṃ ciraṃ naravaśaṃ prāptāḥ svayūthād atha$ ||. In Edgerton's translation EdgertonElephant(1931, 92): `Forest elephants who dwell there happily and by the power of fate have been brought to town in bonds, afflicted by harsh, bitter, cruel words, by excessive grief, fear, bewilderment, bondage, etc., and by sufferings of mind and body, are quite unable for long to sustain life, when from their own herds they have come into the control of men.'

We may treat Łpurūravo$ in Łpāda$ a as a stem form noun or thematised stem, or imagine that the original reading was Łpurūravā$ with double sandhi: Łpurūravās ati$ \rightarrow\ Łpurūravā ati$ \rightarrow\ Łpurūravāti$. ŁPāda$ a may refer to the following passage in the \MBH\ (1.70.16–18, 20ab): purūravās tato vidvān ilāyāṃ samapadyata |
sā vai tasyābhavan mātā pitā ceti hi naḥ śrutam ||
trayodaśa samudrasya dvīpān aśnan purūravāḥ |
amānuṣair vṛtaḥ sattvair mānuṣaḥ san mahāyaśāḥ ||
vipraiḥ sa vigrahaṃ cakre vīryonmattaḥ purūravāḥ |
jahāra ca sa viprāṇāṃ ratnāny utkrośatām api ||
[\dots] tato maharṣibhiḥ kruddhaiḥ śaptaḥ sadyo vyanaśyata | (``The wise Purūravas was born to Ilā. We heard that Ilā was both his mother and his father. The great Purūravas ruled over thirteen islands of the ocean and, though human, he was always surrounded by superhuman beings. Intoxicated with his power, Purūravas quarrelled with some Brahmins and robbed them of their wealth even though they were protesting. [...] Therefore, cursed by the great Ṛṣis, he perished.'') See also \BUDDHACARITA\ 11.15 (Aiḍa = Purūravas): aiḍaś ca rājā tridivaṃ vigāhya
nītvāpi devīṃ vaśam urvaśīṃ tām |
lobhād ṛṣibhyaḥ kanakaṃ jihīrṣur
jagāma nāśaṃ viṣayeṣv atṛptaḥ || For Daṇḍa(ka)'s story, see \RAMAYANA\ 7.71.31 ff.: Daṇḍa meets Arajā, a beautiful girl, in a forest and rapes her. As a consequence, her father, Śukra/Bhārgava, destroyes Daṇḍa's kingdom, which thus becomes the desolate Daṇḍaka-forest.

For two versions of the destruction of Sagara's sons, who were chasing the sacrificial horse of their father's Aśvamedha sacrifice, and by doing so disturbed Kapila's meditation, and who in turn burnt them to ashes, see \MBH\ 3.105.9 ff. and \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 2.52–53. As for Rāvaṇa's haughtiness, especially the fact that he chose to be invincible by all creatures except humans, and its consequences, one should recall the story of the \RAMAYANA\ and Rāvaṇa's destruction brought about by Rāma therein.

Saudāsa, also known as Kalmāṣapāda, hit Śakti, Vasiṣṭha's son, with a whip because the latter did not give way to him, and as a consequence Śakti cursed Saudāsa: Saudāsa had to roam the world as a Rākṣasa for twelve years. See \MBH\ 1.166.1 ff. As for the end of the Yādavas, see the short ŁMausalaparvan$ of the \MBH\ (canto 16): cursed by the sages Viśvāmitra, Kaṇva and Nārada, and seeing menacing omens, the Yādavas take to drinking in Prabhāsa and destroy each other.

Most probably, Łatitṛṣṇā$ in the MSS stand for Łatitṛṣṇāt$ (intending Łatitṛṣṇayā$). The form Łmāndhāto$ in \msCb\ stands for Łmāndhātā$ (nominative of Łmāndhātṛ$). I have corrected it in spite of the fact that the authors' knowledge about his story may come from \DIVYAV\ 17, where it sometimes appears to be an a-stem noun (Łmāndāta$). Łdvijavajñayā$ in Łpāda$ d stands for Łdvijāvajñayā$ metri causa. Māndhātṛ was born from his father's body who, being excessively thirsty once, had drank some decoction prepared for ritual purposes and as a result become pregnant with him. Nevertheless, \BUDDHACARITA\ 11.13 suggests that Māndhātṛ himself was still unsatisfied with wordly objects even after he had obtained half of Indra's throne: devena vṛṣṭe 'pi hiraṇyavarṣe
dvīpān samagrāṃś caturo 'pi jitvā|
śakrasya cārdhāsanam apy avāpya
māndhātur āsīd viṣayeṣv atṛptiḥ||. In fact, as Monika Zin points out (ZinMandhatar149), Māndhātṛ/Māndhāta's rise and fall is a very popular theme in the `Narrative Art of the Amaravati School': `Statistics show that in the Amaravati School the most frequently represented narrative is the story of King Māndhātar, which appears 47 times.' Nahuṣa was elevated to the position of Indra for a period of time and he also wanted to take Śacī, Indra's wife. Indra instructed Śacī to tell Nahuṣa to harness some Ṛsis to a vehicle and use this vehicle to take Śacī. Agastya, one of the Ṛṣis, was insulted even further by Nahuṣa, therefore he cursed Nahuṣa, who then fell from the vehicle. See \MBH\ 12.329.35 ff. and a verse in the \BUDDHACARITA\ (11.14) that follows the one about Māndhātṛ: bhuktvāpi rājyaṃ divi devatānāṃ
śatakratau vṛtrabhayāt pranaṣṭe|
darpān maharṣīn api vāhayitvā
kāmeṣv atṛpto nahuṣaḥ papāta||.

ŁPāda$ a is most probably a reference to Mahābali's promises made to Vāmana that caused his own fall. The ultimate cause of Arjuna' death while the Pāṇḍavas were on the way to the underworld was summarised by Yudhiṣṭhira thus (\MBH\ 17.2.21ab): ekāhnā nirdaheyaṃ vai śatrūn ity arjuno 'bravīt | na ca tat kṛtavān eṣa śūramānī tato 'patat ||. (`Arjuna claimed that he could destroy the enemy in one single day. He failed to do so. He was a boaster, that is why he fell.')

King Nala was an expert in the game of dice but once he lost his kingdom to Puṣkara. See, e.g., \MBH\ 3.56.1 ff. As for Nṛga, see \MBH\ 14.93.74:
gopradānasahasrāṇi dvijebhyo 'dān nṛgo nṛpaḥ |
ekāṃ dattvā sa pārakyāṃ narakaṃ samavāptavān ||. (``King Nṛga had made gifts of thousands of cows for the twice-born. By giving away one single cow that belonged to someone else, he fell into hell.'')

lg.l: svargaṃ ca mokṣaṃ ca sukhaṃ ca nāsti
lg.note: Note how flexible the gender of most nouns is in Łpāda$ b: Łsvarga$, Łmokṣa$ and Łdama$ are usually masculine in standard Sanskrit.

listApp.note: The majority of the witnesses suggest that Łpāda$ c ends in a stem form noun (Łnāśa$). This Łpāda$ is unmetrical, or rather it applies the licence of a word-final short syllable being counted as potentially long (ŁdharMA$).

Note how Łviprā$ in Łpāda$ d is probably an attempt in some MSS to restore the metre. This Łpāda$ is also unmetrical, or rather the licence of a word-final short syllable being counted as potentially long is again applied (ŁviPRA$).
The implications of Łpāda$s ab are not crystal clear to me. Perhaps: such a person has no right for existence in society and has no place in heaven.
The translation of Łparayoni$ in Łpāda$ d is tentative.

Although Ł'nya$ in Łpāda$ a could be interpreted several ways (e.g. Łanye$ for Łanyasmin$, or taken to be the first element of a compound: Łanya-anyāyārtha-$), I think that Łbhūyo 'nyat$ is a fixed expression meaning `something/anything more.' See, e.g., \BHG\ 7.2cd: yaj jñātvā neha bhūyo 'nyaj jñātavyam avaśiṣyate.

In Łpāda$ d, I take Łcaraṇācarāḥ$ as standing for Łcarācarāḥ$ (Łcara-acarāḥ$) metri causa. Alternatively, one may understand it as Łcaraṇacarāḥ$ (metri causa), meaning `those who move on their feet,' perhaps as opposed to snakes (Łbilaga$ or Łbilaṃga$). Neither solution is fully satisfactory. Note that this Łpāda$ also involves a small correction.

lg.note: Note Łmātā$ as a stem form in Łpāda$ d.

rajasvalā ca ṣaṇḍhaś ca nekṣerann aśnato dvijān ||. Translated in OlivelleDharmasutras120 as: `A Cāṇḍāla, a pig, a cock, a dog, a menstruating woman, or a eunuch must not look at the Brahmins while they are eating.'
Understand Łkīrtir yaśo$ as Łkīrtiyaśo$ ('r' being an intrusive consonant here metri causa). Alternatively, as suggested by Francesco Sferra, emend to Łkīrtiṃ yaśo'laṃkṛtām$.

Note the genitive with a verb meaning `to tell' in Łpāda$ a, similarly to 1.38a and \verify.
Similar teachings on Łmauna$ in \DHARMP\ 1.31cd–32ab and \DIVYAV\ 186.21 are quoted in the apparatus.

Possible direct sources for the idea that Łkāma$ is an enemy to be defeated or avoided include \BUDDHACARITA\ 11.17: cīrāmbarā mūlaphalāmbubhakṣā
jaṭā vahanto 'pi bhujaṃgadīrghāḥ |
yair nānyakāryā munayo 'pi bhagnāḥ
kaḥ kāmasaṃjñān mṛgayeta śatrūn ||; see also \BHG\ 3.43: evaṃ buddheḥ paraṃ buddhvā saṃstabhyātmānam ātmanā |
jahi śatruṃ mahābāho kāmarūpaṃ durāsadam ||. As for Łarihā$ in Łpāda$ d, the notion that a saint is a `destroyer of the enemies' [that are evil states of mind] (Łarihanta/arahanta$) in Jainism, but less so in Buddhism, is discussed in GombrichWhat201357–58.

This verse teaches the four Buddhist Łbrahmavihāra$s under the label Łcaturāyatana$. Therfore the word Łāyatana$ seems to be a synonym of Łvihāra$ here, and its use a simple method of appropriating it, turning the list into a Brahmanical one.

lg.note: Note the stem form Łdhyāna$ in Łdhyānādhunā$ (for Łdhyānam adhunā$) in Łpāda$ a.

listApp.note: For contrast, but also for similarities, see the Łdhyānayajña$ section in \VSS\ 6.7ff, in which five types of related meditations are taught. See analysis on pp. Intro \verify.

This verse is difficult to interpret. ŁPāda$s a to d should define Łātman$, Łvidyā$, Łbhava$, and Łsūkṣma$, objects of meditation, respectively. In Łpāda$ a, Łdharmo$ is suspect: it may be the result of an eye-skip to Łpāda$ a of the next verse. ŁPāda$ b might refer to Łtattva$s in an ontological system of 25, 26 or 36 Łtattva$s.

If Łpāda$ c is in fact a reference to a 36-Łtattva$ philosophical system, it is in striking contrast with the 25-Łtattva$ system described in \VSS\ chapter 20. I take Łṣaṭtriṃśa$ as being in stem form.
Note the plural instrumental (Łyair$) with a singular active verb (Łvetti$; anacoluthic structure).
Emending Łmānavaḥ$ to Łmānave$ might err by overcorrection, and Łmānavaḥ$ may have originally been felt like a genitive (`for a person\dots').
Note the stem form noun in Łpāda$ a (Łsthāna$) metri causa, and also that this stem form noun may function as a singular noun next to a number (Łpañca$), a frequently seen phenomenon in this text.

lg.note: See the apparatus to the Sanskrit text for very similar verses in the \MBH, \Manu\ and the \YAJNS, and note how Łpāda$ f slightly deviates from \Manu\ 11.55, which is translated in OlivelleManu217–218 as: `Killing a Brahmin, drinking liquor, stealing, and having sex with an elder's wife–-they call these ``grievous sins causing loss of caste''; and so is establishing any links with such individuals.'

This verse continues quoting \Manu. ŁPāda$ a in the witnesses may actually be no more than the result of misreading of the syllable Łjjha$ in \Manu\ 11.57. Note the variant Łbrahmojjhaṃ vedanindā ca$, in the Southern transmission, in Olivelle's critical edition of \Manu\ (OlivelleManu847).
The text, and my emendation in Łpāda$ c, still follow \Manu\ (11.59).
This is \Manu\ 11.58. I have emended Łrugma$ to Łrukma$ in Łpāda$ d, although Łrugma$ is attested in a great number of Southern MSS and one Śāradā MS in OlivelleManu847.
Perhaps understand Łpāda$ c as Łetan mahāpātakapañcakaṃ$.
Note the confusion of number and gender: understand Łpañca pramādāḥ etā varjanīyāḥ$ or Łpañca prāmādāny etāni varjanīyāni$.

My emendation from Łmanasā dhūryaś$ to Łmana-mādhuryaś$ is based on the fact that following the list of Łyama$s in 3.16cd–17ab, we need some reference to Łmādhurya$ here and that it is easy to see how this corruption came about: Łmano-mādhurya$ would be unmetrical, hence the form Łmana-mādhurya$; Łmana-mā$ is easily corrupted to Łmanasā$ (not to mention the fact that Łmanasā$ comes up in the next verse). In addition, we need five items in this line because of Łpañcamaḥ$. As always, I correct Łmādhūrya$ to Łmādhurya$, although it seems that the former is acceptable in this text. I did not correct Łmādhuryaś$ to Łmādhuryaṃ$ because of the corresponding Łpañcamaḥ$.

ŁPāda$s cd of the previous verse, and Łpāda$s ab of the present one cover four categories of the above: Łcakṣurmādhurya$, Łbuddhimādhurya$, Łdṛṣṭimādhurya$ and Łvāgmādhurya$. This suggests that what follows is on Łkāyamādhurya$.
Emending Łpāda$ d to Łsvāśramābhyāgate gurau$ would make the line smoother, as suggested by Kengo Harimoto.
Understand Łjātavedam$ in Łpāda$ b as Łjātavedasam$ or Łjātavedāḥ$, or rather as belonging to the compound Łdānaṃ$: Łjātavedodānaṃ$.

For Łpāda$ e, see an Āryāgīti verse in the \MAHASUBHS\ (2558): amṛtāyatām iti vadet pīte bhukte kṣute ca śataṃ jīva | choṭikayā saha jṛmbhāsamaye syātāṃ cirāyurānandau || (`When eating or drinking, one should say: ``May it turn into nectar!''; and after sneezing: ``Live for a hundred years!'' By snapping the thumb and forefinger when yawning, there will be long life and happiness.')
Łārjavāḥ$ should be in the accusative, therefore it is to be taken as feminine (rather than neuter) or as an irregular form for Łārjavāni$. I have emended Łpāratoṣikam$ to Łpāritoṣikam$.

My translation of the categories listed here is tentative, the only guiding light being that, if the first line is right, there should be five of them. In addition, I have tried to find categories that seem to be, more or less, in conflict with `sincerity' or `straightness.'

In Łpāda$ a Łpra$ does not make the previous syllable long: this is the phenomenon of `muta cum liquida,' one of the hallmarks of the \VSS, that is, syllables such as Łtra, pra, bra, dra$ do not necessarily make the previous syllable long.

lg.l: iha parata sukhārthaṃ kārayet taṃ manuṣyaḥ

listApp.note: In Łpāda$ b, Łparata$ most probably stands for Łparatra$ or Łparataḥ$ metri causa. We may correct it to Łparatra$, presupposing the presence of the licence `muta cum liquida.'

Łmalapahārī$ in the MSS stands either for Łmalāpahārī$ or Łmalaprahārī$ metri causa. I could have choosen to emend it to Łmalaprahārī$ (again applying the licence `muta cum liquida'), but I decided not to because Łapahārin$, Łapahāra$, Łapahāraka$ are used in the text very frequently. See also 8.44c, which contains a very similar expression: Łsakalamalapahāre dharmapañcāśad etat$.

The chief Ṛtvik (officiating priest) of the Yāga was the sage Kaśyapa and Paraśurāma gave all the lands he conquered till that time to Kaśyapa. Then a plat- form of gold ten yards long and nine yards wide was made and Kaśyapa was installed there and worshipped. After the worship was over according to the instructions from Kaśyapa the gold platform was cut into pieces and the gold pieces were offered to brahmins. The same expression occurs e.g. in VSS 6.2ff, MBh 13.102.8c, Manu 2.86 etc. By this, Łvedāṃś$ becomes difficult to interpret (I supply `recited'). It may be possible to take Łjapa$ as a form deriving from Łjapan$ (present participle) metri causa: Łvedāṃś ca japa$[Łn$] Łyajñāṃś ca kṛtvā$, but in this case the notion of performing sacrifices comes up twice in this verse.

In pāda a, Łahaṃ$ either stands for Łmāṃ$ or the phrase Łjijñāsārtham ahaṃ$ can be translated as `I am to be tested.'
I understand Łgrahaḥ sūryo$ in pāda c as Łsūryagrahaḥ$ (or Łsūryagrahaṇam$): the eclipse of the Sun, which appears to be an auspicious day. See parallels in the apparatus.

Most probaby, Łkandare$ (`in a cave') in pāda b is an early mistake for Łmandare$ (`on Mount Mandara'), a location that appears frequently in the epics and the Purāṇas next to Mount Meru. This is why I conjecture Łmandare$ here.

Understand Łdevalokika$ in pāda c as a stem form compound (metri causa) for a more standard Łdevalaukikaṃ$. Łmartya-m-upajāyate$ in pāda d might be original, with Łm$ as a sandhi bridge. Nevertheless, I emended the pāda to make it clearer.

Pāda a is slightly suspect. It is possible that originally it contained a negation: Łaho 'smi na phalaṃ bhoktā$ (`Ah! I will not eat this fruit'). On the other hand, Łsaphala$ seems to be an odd form in this text simply meaning Łphala$ (see 12.71–72, 108). The translation I have chosen is tentative.
In pāda a, Łtvarita$, for the adverb Łtvaritaṃ$, is in stem form metri causa.

As in 12.70, Łsa phala$, or rather Łsaphala$ might simply mean Łphala$. Here in pāda d I have chosen to print this phrase as two words because here Łsa$ can be grammatically/syntactically correct. See also next line (12.72a).
On the possibility that Łsaphala$ is a form in this text simply signifying Łphala$, see notes on 12.70 and 72.

Łpūrva$[Łṃ$] in pāda d is suspect and difficult to interpret and \Ed\ is probably trying to silently emend it. One possibility is that the pāda originally contained a stem form noun: Łphalāpūrvaṃ manoharam$ (`an unparalleled and charming fruit'). Alternatively, Łpūrva$ is an eyeskip to 12.73b.
I take Łsvāda$ as a stem form noun that stands for the accusative metri causa.

The syntax of pāda c is confusing. I translate it as if it carried a causative meaning (e.g. Łkuru bhīmabalaṃ tv evaṃ$: `make Bhīmabala do like this'). On the other hand, an instrumental would be better (`act like this, together with Bhīmabala'), at least 12.82b hints at this solution.
I accepted the reading Łśreṣṭhī$ in pāda b although it may be a correction of Łśreṣṭhi$, an original Łprātipadika$ of the thematised form of Łśreṣṭhin$ (see 1.63a).

Pāda a could be construed as Łna vane na vane rājan$ (`Your majesty, there is no [such fruit] in any forest'), but a similar expression, Łvanena vanaṃ$, occurs e.g. in MBh 1.144.1 meaning `from forest to forest' (Łte vanena vanaṃ vīrā ghnanto mṛgagaṇān bahūn| apakramya yayū rājaṃs tvaramāṇā mahārathāḥ||$), and this made me choose another option (Łna vanena vane rājan$). \Ed's variant seems like an attempt to `correct' the text.
Pāda a is unmetrical. It is possible the the original read Łbalaṃ$ to avoid this, still meaning the compound Łbhīmabalavākyaṃ$.
I have choosen \msCb's reading in pāda c only because it is metrical. This does not mean that the unmetrical reading of \msCa\msNa\msNc\ cannot have been the original one.

My impression is that Caṇḍa and Vicaṇḍa could be the two royal envoys mentioned in verse 12.126 (Łrājadūtadvayam$), sent along with Bhīmabala to make sure he obeys the king's command. Compare with Śivadharmottara 7.101 (Kenji and Sathya), where Yamas attendants are called Caṇḍa and Mahācaṇḍa.

The reconstruction of pāda d is unsatisfactory and I do not know how to emend Łaram$/Łparam$ at the end of the line. We have to suppose that Bhīmabala is accompanied by Puṇḍaka the foreman of the guild because Vipula's answer seems to be directed towards him.
I conjectured Łtvaram$ for Łtava$ in pāda b because Łtava$ is both unmetrical and meaningless in this context. Łtava$ might have been the result of an eyeskip to pāda d or rather to pāda b of 12.92.

Note the form Łpatañjalam$ metri causa for Łpātañjalam$. It is difficult to say if Łsāṃkhya yoga$ in pāda d signifies one or two things. I have chosen to separate them, interpreting Łsāṃkhya$ as a stem form noun, because in other parts of the text, Łsāṃkhya$ and Łyoga$ are usually treated as two different traditions. See 8.1–3, 16.36–37, and 23.5c. Understand Łpatañjalam$ as Łpātañjalaḥ$ (metri causa and gender confusion). Another, less likely, possibility is that here Łsāṃkhyayoga$ and Łpātañjalayoga$ are contrasted.

Understand Łmūrtimān$ in pāda d as Łmūrtimantaḥ$. Note also \msCb\ and \msCc's attempt to include the Atharvaveda. I find it more likely that by Łarthaveda$ Kauṭilya's Arthaśāstra is being referred to here.

Łiyaṃ$ (f.) in pāda a stands for either Łayaṃ$ (m.) or Łidaṃ$ (n.), agreeing with the gender of Łvimāna$. Alternatively, the sentence wants, rather clumsily, to convey the meaning `all these millions of aerial palaces...'.
Note that here, as often in this text, nouns stand in the singular after numbers such as a thousand.

Understand Łtavārthīyopasarpanti$ as Łtavārthīyā upasarpanti$ (double sandhi). Łtavārthāyo$ may work as well (\msCb\ and \msNa) but I consider Łtavārtīyo$ the lectio difficilior, thus potentially the original reading.

We are forced to accept \Ed's reading of Łbhayatrasta$ here because it if far superior to the readings of all other witnesses. The rejected reading (Łbhayas tatra$) may have been the result of a simple metathesis (Łtra-sta$ to Łsta-tra$).
The compound Łbrahmalokapitāmahaḥ$ may sound slightly odd as an epithet of Brahmā but it does occur in the MBh (12.336.30b) and in other texts (Padmasaṃhitā 3.193d, Jayadrathayāmala 3.14.198b).

Medhā- tithi was the son born to Priyavrata of Sarūpā. Agnī- dhra, and others were the brothers of Medhātithi. Medhātithi became the King of Plakṣadvīpa after the death of Priyavrata. (8th Skandha, Devī Bhāgavata). Medhātithi got seven sons named Śāntahaya, Śiśira, Sukhodaya, Ānanda, Śiva. Kṣemaka and Dhruva. They all became Kings of Plakṣadvīpa. The countries they ruled were named after them as Śāntahayavarṣa, Śiśira- varṣa, Sukhodayavarṣa, Ānandavarṣa, Śivavarṣa, Kṣema- kavarṣa and Dhruvavarṣa. There are seven mountains showing the boundaries of these states and they are called Gomeda, Cāndra, Nārada, Dundubhi, Somaka, Sumana and Vaibhrāja. In these beautiful countries and grand mountains live a great many Devas, Gandharvas and virtuous men. (Chapter 4, Aṃśa 2, Viṣṇu Purāṇa).''
